School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Jiangsu Ocean University Lianyungang 222005 China A convenient method for preparing palladium nanocatalyst and its application in the Heck coupling reactions between various aryl halides and olefins are presented. Pd nanoparticles were photoreduced on anodic TiO2 nanotubes (ATNTs) to prepare the Pd@ATNTs catalyst by utilizing the large specific surface area of the ATNTs' hollow tubes. Pd nanoparticles were found to be highly dispersed on the walls of the nanotubes with an average particle size of 8.01 nm by characterization techniques. The heterogeneous Pd@ATNTs catalyst showed excellent catalytic efficiency (TOF up to 1010 h−1) due to the highly dispersed Pd within the ATNTs. Pd@ATNTs has remarkable properties of ease of separation and good reusability, allowing for at least 10 cycles of recovery and reuse without a significant decrease in catalytic activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Anodic TiO2 nanotubes Photoreduction Supported palladium catalysts Heck reaction Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The carbon-carbon cross-coupling reaction is one of the most important techniques for the preparation of various types of organics in the fine chemicals industry [1]. Among many coupling reactions, the Heck reaction is a significant reaction for the formation of carbon-carbon bonds by cross-coupling aryl halides and alkenes on homogeneous catalysts [2,3]. Commonly used homogeneous catalysts such as Pd(OAc)2 [4] and Pd(PPh3)4 [5] present a challenge for separation and recycling in practical applications [6]. Therefore, catalyst recycling has become a topic of significant interest in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Over the past few decades, significant efforts have been devoted to developing heterogeneous catalysts via the immobilization of Pd nanoparticles on diverse supports, including metal oxides [7], MOF [8,9], silica [10], and polymers [11,12]. Heterogeneous Pd catalysts not only have the advantage of easy separation in industrial applications, but also exhibit reduced Pd leaching due to the tight binding of Pd nanoparticles to the catalyst. However, heterogeneous catalysis still faces the challenge of catalyst recovery and stability, which ultimately leads to a considerable decrease in their catalytic activity [13]. Hence, it is of paramount importance to develop supports that are better suited for Pd nanoparticles loading. TiO2 has garnered significant attention as a versatile metal oxide material, owing to its large bandgap, high stability, low toxicity and cost-effectiveness, and has been extensively studied for a variety of applications, including photocatalysis [14–16], supercapacitors [17,18], and solar cells [19,20]. Additionally, TiO2 is considered to be a good support for noble metal nanocatalysts [21]. In practice, the most commonly used crystalline forms of TiO2 are anatase and rutile, with different crystalline forms having different properties and applications. TiO2 synthesized at room temperature usually exists in an amorphous form. Thermodynamically, rutile TiO2 is more stable than anatase. Upon heat treatment in air, the amorphous form is converted irreversibly to anatase (∼300–500 °C) or rutile (>550 °C) [22,23]. However, the more dense structure of rutile results in less catalytic activity than anatase [24]. To date, numerous studies have been dedicated to scrutinizing the morphological features of TiO2, including nanoparticles [25], nanorods [26], nanofibers [27], and nanotubes [28,29], which have significant implications for the loading of Pd nanoparticles. Among these nanostructures, the uniformly ordered channel structure of anodic TiO2 nanotubes (ATNTs) not only provides a relatively large specific surface area, but the ATNTs bonded to the Ti substrate are more easily recovered [30,31]. Anodization in an F-containing electrolyte was employed to prepare ATNTs, offering the advantage of precise control over morphological properties such as tube diameter and length by adjusting the applied voltage and oxidation time [32]. As a result, the fabricated ATNTs exhibit a distinctive honeycomb-like nanopore structure. Therefore, the facile synthesis of ATNTs with a large specific surface area and high aspect ratio offers a promising strategy for the fabrication of heterogeneous Pd catalysts. Based on our previous research on anodic TiO2 nanotubes [33–35] and noble metal catalysis [36–39], we believe that exploiting the unique structural characteristics and physical properties of anodic TiO2 nanotubes for loading noble metals is a worthwhile endeavor. In this study, the ATNTs were prepared via anodization in the ethylene glycol system and subsequently transformed into the anatase crystalline form through annealing. The advantage of the nanotubes prepared using this method is that they are bonded to the titanium substrate, which allows for convenient separation from the reaction system. The anatase ATNTs were then immersed in the Pd precursor solution and subjected to 1 h of irradiation using a mercury lamp to achieve uniform loading of Pd onto the walls of the ATNTs. The catalytic performance of Pd@ATNTs was evaluated by Heck coupling reactions between aryl iodides and methyl acrylate. The utilization of Pd@ATNTs leads to a high reaction conversion (>99%) within 90 min (Fig. 1 ). Notably, the Pd@ATNTs exhibited consistent catalytic activity even after undergoing 10 cycles, demonstrating their excellent reusability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and characterization Tetraammine dichloropalladium (Pd(NH3)4Cl2) was acquired from d-chem Co., Ltd. Iodobenzene and methyl acrylate of reagent grade were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Other substrates were provided by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All the chemicals were used without any further purification. The crystal structure of the as-anodized TiO2 nanotubes was characterized on a Philips X' pert Pro-X-ray diffractometer equipped with CuKα radiation. The morphology of the samples was analyzed using a high-resolution scanning electron microscope (FESEM-7600F) and a transmission electron microscope (JEOL JEM-2100F). A Thermo Fisher Escalab 250xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source was used for the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. A BeiShiDe 3H-2000PM1 Specific surface and pore size analyzer was used to measure the specific surface area. The Pd content in the collected liquid and solid samples was quantified using an Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES Thermo Fisher i CAP 6300). NMR analysis of purified products using a Bruker Avance 500 spectrometer. 2.2 Synthesis of the ATNTs Amorphous ATNTs were prepared by the anodization process, which was similar to our previous report [40]. The titanium foils were ultrasonically cleaned with acetone and deionized water for 15 min respectively. The foils were subsequently polished using a mixture of HNO3, HF, and deionized water (1:1:3 by volume) for approximately 15 s. All specimens were thoroughly rinsed with deionized water and dried in air. The clean titanium foils were utilized as the anode while the graphite sheet served as the cathode, with a 3 cm separation between the two electrodes. The anodization was conducted in a glycol electrolyte containing 0.5 wt% NH4F and 2 wt% H2O at a constant voltage of 40 V for 40 min. The temperature of electrolyte was controlled at 20 °C. After anodization, the specimens were rinsed with deionized water and subsequently dried in air. To induce the transformation of amorphous ATNTs to anatase, all specimens were subjected to annealing in ambient air at 450 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. 2.3 Synthesis of the Pd@ATNTs The ATNTs were immersed in 1 mM Pd(NH3)4Cl2 solution and impregnated for 30 min at room temperature under vacuum, followed by 30 min of magnetic stirring. The ATNTs were transferred into a quartz tube along with the solution, followed by irradiation with a 500 W mercury lamp for 1 h. The ATNTs were irradiated twice on both sides for 15 min each to produce Pd nanoparticles. Finally, the resulting product was rinsed three times with deionized water and then dried overnight at 60 °C under vacuum. 2.4 General procedure for the Heck reactions A typical reaction involved adding iodobenzene (1 mmol), methyl methacrylate (1.5 mmol), Et3N (1.5 mmol), DMF (2 mL), and the Pd@ATNTs catalyst to a 10 mL reaction tube, followed by stirring at 100 °C. Gas chromatography (Agilent 7820A) was used to monitor the reaction. The conversion was determined based on the consumption of iodobenzene, while the turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by dividing the hourly iodobenzene consumption (mol h−1) by the amount of Pd on the ATNTs' walls. After the reaction, the catalyst was directly removed with tweezers and washed with DMF for using in the next reaction. The remaining reaction solution was mixed with deionized water, and the aqueous layer was extracted with ethyl acetate. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and concentrated to give the crude product. The crude products were purified and characterized by 1H NMR analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Pd@ATNTs Fig. 2 shows the XRD spectra of the unannealed and annealed ATNTs, Pd@ATNTs and Pd@ATNTs catalyst after the Heck reaction, respectively. In Fig. 2a, the diffraction peaks of the prepared ATNTs match with the substrate metal Ti's characteristic diffraction peaks (JCPDS No. 44–1294), indicating that the unannealed ATNTs are amorphous. The diffraction peaks of annealed ATNTs, as shown in Fig. 2b, are consistent with the standard PDF card (JCPDS No. 21–1272), indicating successful transformation of the amorphous ATNTs into crystalline anatase form through high-temperature calcination, consistent with the literature [23]. Fig. 2c shows no significant diffraction peaks corresponding to Pd were observed in the XRD patterns of the prepared catalyst, which can be attributed to the low loading and uniform distribution of Pd nanoparticles [41]. The palladium content of the heterogeneous Pd@ATNTs catalyst was determined to be 4.5 × 10−4 mmol/cm2 by ICP-OES. Fig. S1 displays the optical images of various samples. The colors of the unannealed ATNTs, annealed ATNTs and Pd@ATNTs are translucent, gray and black respectively. Scanning electron microscopy and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy were used to characterize the surface morphology and particle size of the Pd@ATNTs. Fig. 3 a illustrates the morphology of ATNTs prepared via anodization in a glycol solution containing F−, which were subsequently annealed at 450 °C to transform into the anatase crystal form. The SEM images reveal the highly ordered tubular morphology of the ATNTs, with an inner diameter of 33.3 nm (Fig. S2) and a tube length of 3.070 μm. The high aspect ratio of the nanotubes facilitates the loading of a greater number of Pd nanoparticles. The Pd nanoparticles exhibited uniform dispersion both inside and outside the nanotube walls, as demonstrated in Fig. 3b. The uniform distribution of Pd nanoparticles facilitated their stable binding to the support, which is crucial for their effective use in the catalytic Heck reaction. Based on the analysis of particle size distribution, it is evident that the Pd nanoparticles range in size from 5 to 12 nm, with an average particle size of 8.01 nm (Fig. 3d). Furthermore, the HRTEM image in Fig. 3e exhibits distinct and periodic lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.22 nm, which is consistent with the (111) crystal plane of Pd [42]. HAADF-STEM image of Pd@ATNTs in Fig. 4 clearly depicts the nanotube structure of ATNTs, which is in consistent with the SEM results. EDX analysis demonstrates the presence of Pd, Ti, and O elements in the catalyst (Fig. S3) and elemental mapping of Pd confirms the high dispersion of Pd nanoparticles on the ATNTs. Moreover, the presence of Pd elements in the synthesized catalyst provides evidence for the successful preparation of catalyst loaded with Pd nanoparticles. The XPS analysis of catalyst demonstrates the compositions and valence states of Pd@ATNTs. The XPS scan spectrum of Pd@ATNTs reveals the presence of Pd, Ti and O elements in the catalyst, indicating that the Pd nanoparticles were successfully loaded on the nanotubes (Fig. S4). The high resolution XPS spectra of Ti 2p and Pd 3d are given in Fig. 5 . The two characteristic peaks at 464.5 eV and 458.7 eV are attributed to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2, respectively (Fig. 5a). The XPS results show that Pd is mainly present in the Pd@ATNTs catalyst in the Pd0 valence state, with a small amount of Pd2+ valence state (Fig. 5b). The Pd 3d spectrum is deconvoluted into two sets of double peaks at 334.7 eV (Pd0 3d5/2), 335.9 eV (Pd2+ 3d5/2), 340 eV (Pd0 3d3/2) and 341.3 eV (Pd2+ 3d3/2), indicating that photoreduction can efficiently convert the Pd precursor to Pd0. Fig. 6 illustrates the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for ATNTs and Pd@ATNTs. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm for both showed a type IV isotherm (IUPAC category) with an apparent hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of mesoporous structural features in the material [43]. The Table 1 summarizes the specific surface area, average pore size, and pore volume of both ATNTs and Pd@ATNTs. Compared to the specific surface area of ATNTs (52.5 m2 g−1), the surface area of Pd@ATNTs decreased to 39.0 m2 g−1 after Pd loading. Meanwhile, its pore volume decreased from 0.254 cm3 g−1 to 0.244 cm3 g−1 and its average pore size decreased from 26.1 nm to 18.6 nm, which may be attributed to the incorporation of Pd nanoparticles into the nanotubes. These results are consistent with the SEM image (Fig. S2). 3.2 Catalytic activity of Pd@ATNTs for Heck coupling reaction In order to evaluate the chemical catalytic activity of the Pd@ATNTs heterogeneous catalyst, we employed the Heck reaction of iodobenzene and methyl acrylate as a model reaction. Control experiments were conducted under conditions without any catalyst or using anatase ATNTs as the catalyst (Table 2 , entries 1, 2). No product was detected after 90 min, indicating that the Heck reaction does not occur in the absence of a catalyst and that ATNTs are not effective catalysts for the Heck reaction. Furthermore, the effects of reaction variables such as catalyst amount, reaction time, temperature, base and solvent on the Heck reaction was investigated. The conversion increased gradually as the amount of catalyst was increased from 0.045 mol% to 0.180 mol% (entries 3–5). Nevertheless, the increasing trend in conversion slows down at a catalyst dosage of 0.180 mol%. By varying the reaction time from 30 min to 90 min (entries 5–7), model experiments were performed. Almost complete conversion achieved after 90 min. Temperature plays a crucial role in the target reaction, and the model reaction was carried out at three different temperatures (60, 80 and 100 °C) (entries 7–9). At a lower temperature of 80 °C, the reaction conversion was 62.2% after 90 min (entry 8), and at a further decreased temperature of 60 °C, the conversion was only 17.5% after 180 min (entry 9). The results indicate that temperature has a strong influence on the reaction and that higher temperatures are required to achieve high conversions. When Na2CO3, K2CO3, or NaOAc were used as the base in the reaction (entries 10–12), the conversion of the reaction was low, likely due to the relatively poor solubility of the inorganic base in organic solvents, which makes it difficult to neutralize the acid generated during the reaction and therefore reduces the reaction rate [44]. In summary, the Heck reaction has the highest conversion when only Et3N is used as a base. When a polar non-protonic solvent was used as the reaction solvent (entries 7, 13–14), the conversion of the reaction was higher, probably because the polar protonic solvent (entry 16) and the non-polar solvent (entry 15) were not conducive to the progression of the Heck reaction [45]. Among several polar non-protonic solvents, DMF exhibits the highest conversion, possibly owing to its high polarity, high dielectric constant, and good coordination properties [46]. After exploring the impact of various reaction parameters, the study continued with a series of Heck reactions of a variety of aryl iodides with methyl acrylate under identical reaction conditions (Table 3 ). The results show that the Pd@ATNTs catalyst displayed good conversion for the Heck reaction of a wide range of functionalized substrates with methyl acrylate, indicating that the prepared Pd@ATNTs catalyst was generally applicable for this type of reaction. The reaction rate of aryl iodides with electron-absorbing groups was faster than that of aryl iodides with electron-giving groups due to the substituent effect. The aryl iodides containing electron-withdrawing groups on the benzene ring exhibit high conversion, leading to the formation of the corresponding products within 40–90 min. (entries 1–6) [13,47]. Conversely, when the substituent on the benzene ring was an electron-donating group, the conversion of aryl iodides decreased but still exhibited acceptable catalytic activity (entries 7–10). However, the conversion of o-methyl iodobenzene was lower than that of m-methyl and p-methyl due to the presence of spatial site resistance. Table 4 shows the results of the Heck reaction of various aromatic halides with different olefins. It can be observed that bromobenzene and chlorobenzene had slow reactions with methyl acrylate (Table 4, entries 3, 5), indicating that the catalyst has poor catalytic properties for these substrates. The reaction time was extended, but the reaction of bromobenzene and chlorobenzene still did not occur. Considering the low boiling point effect of the base and substrate, we used a high boiling point base (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane, DABCO) and substrate as an alternative, which resulted in an observed improvement in reaction conversion (entries 4, 6). Styrene, acrylic acid, and ethyl acrylate were also used as substrates in the catalytic tests, resulting in conversions of 94.3% (entry 1), 94.4% (entry 7) and >99% (entry 8), respectively. Reusability, which determines the importance of heterogeneous catalysts in practical applications, is the main feature of heterogeneous catalysts. Fig. 7 a shows the cycling stability performance of the Pd@ATNTs. At the end of the reaction, the Pd@ATNTs could be removed directly from the reaction solution and used in subsequent reactions. The catalyst maintained its catalytic activity after 10 cycles with a conversion of 92.5%. It could be attributed to the slight fracturing of the nanotubes and the loss of some Pd due to the mechanical stirring, which is further verified by the SEM analysis of Pd@ATNTs after 10 cycles. The SEM image (Fig. 3c) shows that although the nanotubes fractured and resulted in the loss of Pd at the end of the Heck coupling reaction, Pd still remained on the walls of the ATNTs and the tubular structure of the nanotubes was retained, confirming the stability of the catalyst. Subsequently, we analyzed the Pd content of the pre-reaction Pd@ATNTs and post-reaction solution by ICP-OES and calculated that only 0.6% of Pd was leached, which demonstrated the high stability of the Pd@ATNTs catalyst and that the Pd nanoparticles were strongly bound to the nanotubes of the ATNTs. The optical images of the reaction system before and after the Heck reaction is shown in Fig. S5. A comparison of the conversions before and after hot filtration was conducted, and the results are shown in Fig. 7b. The graph clearly indicates that the catalyst was filtered out while hot after 20 min, and subsequent conversions leveled off, which demonstrates limited leaching of Pd in the solution and the stable catalytic performance of the catalyst. The changes in Pd nanoparticles were analyzed by XPS and TEM (Figs. S6 and S7) after recovering the catalyst from the reaction mixture. The peak integrated area analysis of XPS spectra before and after the reaction revealed a reduction in the area ratio of Pd (II)/Pd (0) from 26.5 to 23.1%, which may be due to the fact that Pd (0) was basically unchanged after recirculation. The XRD pattern of the Pd@ATNTs after the reaction (Fig. 2d) is similar to that before the reaction (Fig. 2c), which may be due to the good dispersion of Pd on the catalyst after the reaction, consistent with the TEM results (Fig. S7) and the absence of significant agglomeration. The particle size distribution diagram of Pd nanoparticles indicates that the particle size distribution remained largely unchanged compared to before the reaction, with an average particle size of 9.12 nm. ICP analysis of the recycled Pd@ATNTs catalyst (4 cycles) was conducted to determine the remaining Pd content, and the results showed that the content of Pd was still 4.4 × 10−4 mmol/cm2. Based on the aforementioned results, we believe that the Heck reaction catalyzed by Pd@ATNTs follows the leaching-redeposition mechanism, which includes the oxidative addition of aryl halides and Pd (0), followed by migratory insertion, β-H elimination, and reductive elimination. At the end of the process, Pd (II) undergoes reduction back to Pd (0). Pd leaching is due to the oxidative addition of iodobenzene to Pd (0) to form soluble Pd (II) [48–50]. Nevertheless, the mesoporous confinement effect of ATNTs retains Pd (II) within the nanotubes, making it less susceptible to loss [51]. After the reaction, the dissolved Pd (II) could redeposit on bare surface of support [52]. The proposed general Heck reaction mechanism for arylation using the Pd@ATNTs catalytic systems is given in Fig. 8 . Table 5 shows a comparison of the activity of our work with that of other catalysts reported in the literature for the Heck coupling reaction between iodobenzene and methyl acrylate. Compared to the literature, the high TOF value of the Pd@ATNTs catalyst confirms its excellent catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have prepared efficient and stable catalyst for Pd@ATNTs by anodization and a simple photoreduction method. The formation of highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles with an average particle size of approximately 8.01 nm on the walls of the ATNTs was confirmed by XRD, SEM, TEM and XPS characterization. The Pd@ATNTs catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity for the Heck coupling reaction of iodobenzene and methyl acrylate, as well as good catalytic performance for different substrates. The catalyst showed excellent recyclability, maintaining high activity for at least 10 consecutive runs with no significant loss of activity. The successful preparation of Pd@ATNTs catalyst and their excellent performance demonstrate the promising potential and development of ATNTs-based catalysts in catalysis. coredata.dc:description: A convenient method for preparing palladium nanocatalyst and its application in the Heck coupling reactions between various aryl halides and olefins are presented. Pd nanoparticles were photoreduced on anodic TiO2 nanotubes (ATNTs) to prepare the Pd@ATNTs catalyst by utilizing the large specific surface area of the ATNTs' hollow tubes. Pd nanoparticles were found to be highly dispersed on the walls of the nanotubes with an average particle size of 8.01 nm by characterization techniques. The heterogeneous Pd@ATNTs catalyst showed excellent catalytic efficiency (TOF up to 1010 h−1) due to the highly dispersed Pd within the ATNTs. Pd@ATNTs has remarkable properties of ease of separation and good reusability, allowing for at least 10 cycles of recovery and reuse without a significant decrease in catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Anodic TiO2 nanotubes supported palladium catalysts for Heck coupling reactions: Excellent catalytic activity and reusability
